abstract.p: Indonesia's biggest foreign donors agree to extend it $4.8 billion in credit to help it offset next year's government deficit and add $530 million for what they call technical assistance; World Bank, which leads Consultative Group on Indonesia, says donors are convinced that Indonesia will satisfy demands for greater progress on economic restructuring and on pacifying renegade militias in timor (S)

block.p: Indonesia's biggest foreign donors agreed to extend it $4.8 billion in credit to help it offset next year's government deficit and added $530 million for what they called technical assistance. The World Bank, which leads the Consultative Group on Indonesia, said the donors were convinced that Jakarta would satisfy demands for greater progress on economic restructuring and on pacifying renegade militias in Timor. Economists had predicted that donors, led by Japan, had too much invested in Indonesia's economic recovery to make aid contingent on the military situation in Timor, over which many believe the government has little effective control.
